input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.

Artest volunteered no contest in May to a misdemeanor community service charge that stemmed from a partnership with his wife on March 5. input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you avoid staying away from online-focused discussion forums frequently, you end up believing that the past is void of metadata. Now, this metadata might or might not be HTML, or it might or might not be SQL or JSON or a few other systems with unremarkable names like “data model” in their categories. It might or might not be the long-forgotten (and often celebrated) “Static Web.” In fact, it might or might not be a few outdated terms, and it might or might not be a bad thing. But whatever the past was, it certainly was empty of metadata; on this the novices disagree. To my observation there’s an opportunity with this: the debate always seems to rely on technologies which do exist or are overly abundant, so it always advances to discussing how things were “in the past,” which will always remain. Surprisingly, there's a difficult way to remove loads of metadata from your texts right this second, without having to forget anything less simple than new CSS3. If it fades away, “the past” might disappear a lot faster than anticipated.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you linger in tech-focused discussion forums often enough, you begin to doubt that the past was devoid of metadata. Now, this metadata might or not be CSV, or it might not be JSON or YAML or numerous other methods with mundane titles like “data table” in their descriptions. It might not be the once-hyped (and frequently mocked) “Static Web.” In truth, it might not be countless outdated terms, and it might not be a bad thing. But whatever the past was, it definitely lacked metadata; on this the skeptics concur. To my view, there’s a solution to this: the debate always appears to hinge on technologies which have vanished or are obsolete, so it constantly returns to discussing how things were “in the past,” which might always remain behind us. Fortunately, there's a difficult way to remove vast amounts of metadata from your files right this second, without having to forget anything as simple as modern HTML5. If it falls out of favor, “the past” might stay further away than expected.
